title: 114_hr4370
content: The "Compact Impact Relief Act of 2016" may adjust the FMAP for affected jurisdictions equivalent to Compact migrant expenditures. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will increase the FMAP for affected jurisdictions after the enactment of the Act. The chief executive official of the affected jurisdiction must estimate the amount of Compact migrant expenditures. The affected jurisdiction must estimate the amount of compact migrant expenditures for each quarter and submit it to the Secretary of the Interior. The Secretary of the Interior will review and adjust the estimation before submitting a final amount to the Secretary of Health and Human Services. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will estimate the increase in FMAP needed for each affected jurisdiction to result in higher Federal payments under title XIX of the Social Security Act equivalent to the final estimated compact migrant expenditures. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will notify each chief executive official of any increase in the FMAP estimated for affected jurisdictions under title XIX of the Social Security Act, exceeding certain limitations. For each calendar quarter with an FMAP increase for affected jurisdictions, the chief executive official must report total compact migrant expenditures to the Secretary of the Interior. The report must be in a specified form and manner. The Secretary of Health and Human Services reviews and adjusts accounting submitted by the Secretary of the Interior for accuracy, and submits a final accounting of compact migrant expenditures to the Secretary of Health and Human Services. The Secretary of Health and Human Services also reviews the FMAP increase for affected jurisdictions and makes any necessary adjustments. The FMAP for affected jurisdictions is adjusted based on the final accounting of compact migrant expenditures submitted, subject to certain limitations. The FMAP for affected jurisdictions is adjusted for overpayments or underpayments in future quarters. The increase in FMAP cannot exceed 100 percent. Compact migrant expenditures are not considered medical assistance under title XIX of the Social Security Act. The term "affected jurisdiction" is defined in section 104(e)(2) of the Compact of Free Association Amendments Act of 2003. Compact migrant expenditures refer to non-Federal funds spent on services for qualified nonimmigrants as per section 1905(a) of the Social Security Act. The term "FMAP" refers to the Federal medical assistance percentage under U.S.C. 1396d(a) for qualified nonimmigrants and related administrative costs, including payments to health care providers for services not covered by a State plan under title XIX of the Social Security Act. The term "FMAP" refers to the Federal medical assistance percentage under U.S.C. 1396d(b), as defined in the Social Security Act, without regard to the Compact Impact Relief Act of 2016. SEC. 3. PAYMENTS RELATING TO ELEMENTARY AND SECONDARY EDUCATION OF CITIZENS OF FREELY ASSOCIATED STATES. Amendments are made to the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 to include educating alien children from the Freely Associated States as citizens of the United States. Additionally, changes are made to payments for eligible federally connected children under the Act. Amendments to the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 include allowing alien children from the Freely Associated States to be educated as US citizens. Changes are also made to payments for eligible federally connected children under the Act, including those from the Republic of the Marshall Islands, the Federated States of Micronesia, or the Republic of Palau. Additional funding of $10,000,000 is authorized annually for federally connected children under the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965. This includes a provision to increase funding by 1.25 times for children described in paragraph (1)(H). SEC. 4. Preference for U.S. citizens or nationals for housing financial assistance in Guam and the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands. United States citizens or nationals are given priority over eligible aliens for financial assistance. SEC. 5. Independent assessment of strategic importance of relationship between the United States and the Marshall Islands, the Federated States of Micronesia, and Palau. The Secretary of State will seek an agreement with an eligible organization to assess the strategic importance of the relationship between the United States and the Marshall Islands, Micronesia, and Palau, as part of the Asia-Pacific re-balance and for security purposes. The Secretary of State will assess the capabilities and effectiveness of US agencies in administering the Compacts of Free Association with the Marshall Islands, Micronesia, and Palau, including recommendations for improvements. The eligible organization entering into an agreement under this section must submit a report to the Secretary of State within one year of the Act's enactment. The report should include an assessment of necessary changes, recommendations for future administration of Compacts, and any other relevant matters. The eligible organization must submit a report to the Secretary of State within one year, including an assessment, recommendations, and any other relevant matters. The report should be unclassified but may have a classified annex if needed. The organization can obtain necessary information from US departments or agencies. Upon request, the head of the department or agency will provide information to the eligible organization.
